summary: When using `continueAsNew` to restart a workflow, the workflow type name is incorrectly passed as a fully-qualified class name instead of the registered short name, causing the worker to fail with 'unable to find workflow type' errors.
userImpact: Users attempting to implement self-restarting workflows using continueAsNew encounter worker failures and unable to resume workflow execution.
rootCause: The continueAsNew method appears to be using the fully-qualified class name (FQDN) instead of the short registered workflow type name when continuing the workflow.
workaround: Replace generator-based workflow type collection with an array-based collection in the registry, though the root cause remains unclear.
resolutionDetails: Reporter could not reproduce the issue with latest versions and closed it. The workaround worked but root cause was never definitively identified.
keyQuote: unable to find workflow type: Application\BusinessProcess\ZeroBalance\ZeroBalanceWorkflow. Supported types: [ZeroBalanceWorkflow]
